facts.text: Kariya and his wife Sava purchased the house in dispute by a registered deed on April 2, 1905.
Kariya died in 1936 leaving behind Sava and Ram Charan, his son.
On August 16, 1951 Ram Charan mortgaged the house to Prem Raj the appellant.
Prem Raj obtained a preliminary decree for foreclosure on August 16, 1952 and final decree on July 16, 1955.
On March 7, 1952 Sava gifted the entire house to Prakash Chandra, son of Ram Charan, the respondent.
Prakash Chandra frustrated several attempts of the appellant to get possession in execution of his decree. Three unsuccessful attempts till end of 1954.
Fourth execution attempt by appellant on April 25, 1956.

On December 7, 1956, Prakash Chandra instituted suit against appellant and Ram Charan for declaration that preliminary and final foreclosure decrees not binding on him and perpetual injunction restraining possession.
Appeal filed, stay of execution ordered December 31, 1958.
Appeal court partly allowed on October 21, 1959: Prakash owner of half share by gift, injunction re half share.
Appellant filed second appeal in High Court, Prakash cross-objection for remaining half. Both dismissed January 1, 1962.
Fourth execution application dismissed June 23, 1956 for non-payment of process fee.
Fifth execution application filed July 29, 1964 for possession over half of the house.
Execution court and appellate court disallowed limitation objection, High Court upheld it, dismissed application as time-barred on February 3, 1967.

legal_issues.text: Whether the fifth execution application is barred by limitation under Article 182 of Limitation Act, 1908, and whether limitation saved by clauses 1,2,4,5 of Art. 182, S.15, or as revival of fourth application.

petitioner_arguments.text: Limitation saved by clauses 1,2,4 of Art. 182 due to High Court decree in Prakash Chandra's suit.
Limitation saved by cl.5 of Art.182: written statement, resistance to appeal, second appeal are applications/steps in aid of execution in proper court.
Fifth application is to revive the fourth execution proceeding, not time-barred.

respondent_arguments.text: Fifth execution application time-barred; S.15 does not apply as stay only limited period; Art.182 cl.2 not applicable as appeal not against foreclosure decree.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Article 182 Limitation Act 1908; Section 15 Limitation Act 1908

court_reasoning.text: Cl.1 of Art.182 not applicable: High Court decree in collateral suit did not reverse/vary/amend foreclosure decree; starting point remains date of foreclosure decree.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Foreclosure decree remained intact against respondent; Prakash's suit collateral.

court_reasoning.text: Written statement not an 'application' under cl.5 Art.182 as no request to court; appeal to High Court not to proper court (execution court).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Proper court is court executing decree; resistance in collateral suit not step in aid.

court_reasoning.text: Fifth application not revival: fourth dismissed finally for default (non-payment process fee), not pending.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Revival requires previous application pending or dismissed for no fault of decree-holder.

court_reasoning.text: Dissent (Goswami J.): Steps in Prakash's suit and appeals are steps in aid under Art.182(5) as direct connection to execution, removing obstacle to half share.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Nexus between collateral suit and foreclosure decree; liberal construction favors decree-holder.

holdings.text: Fifth execution application time-barred; no saving under Art.182 clauses 1,2,4,5 or as revival.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bhawanipore Banking Corporation Ltd. v. Gori Shanker Sharma
precedents_cited.relevance: Appeal in collateral proceeding does not give fresh starting point under Art.182 cl.2,4.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mohammad Jabir v. Narain Prasad Daruka
precedents_cited.relevance: Decree itself amended, cl.4 applicable; not so here.

precedents_cited.case_name: Janab Mohammad Ismail v. Tatlvia Bivi Amral
precedents_cited.relevance: Decree amended, unlike here.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rudra Narain v. Maharaja of Kapurthala
precedents_cited.relevance: Plaint may be application under cl.5.

precedents_cited.case_name: Raghunandan Prasad v. Bhaggoolal
precedents_cited.relevance: Plaint not application.

precedents_cited.case_name: Panna Lal v. Smt. Saraswati Devi
precedents_cited.relevance: Written objection as application/step in aid; assumption wrong.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kartar Singh v. Sultan Singh Partap Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Written objection as application; erroneous.

precedents_cited.case_name: V.E.A. Annamalai Chettiar v. Valliammai Achi
precedents_cited.relevance: Appeal from execution court order; High Court proper court then.

precedents_cited.case_name: Baldeo Singh v. Ram Swarup
precedents_cited.relevance: Appeal as step in aid; did not consider proper court.

precedents_cited.case_name: Joshi Laxmiram Lallubhai Mehta Balashankar Veniram v. ?
precedents_cited.relevance: Appeal against insolvency order as step; no proper court consideration.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chatnangali Rarichan v. Puvvanparambath Kunhamu
precedents_cited.relevance: Insolvency application not to proper court.

precedents_cited.case_name: C. P. Syndicate Ltd. Nagpur v. Firm Hasanali Abdul Ali
precedents_cited.relevance: Appeal from execution court.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rajendra Prasad v. Indrasan Prasad
precedents_cited.relevance: Appeal from execution court.

precedents_cited.case_name: Vadlamannati Bala Tripura Sundaramma v. Abdul Khader
precedents_cited.relevance: Revival conditions: pending or dismissed no fault.

precedents_cited.case_name: Prem Narain v. Ganga Ram
precedents_cited.relevance: Execution struck off per compromise, not final.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hira Lal v. Punjab National Bank
precedents_cited.relevance: Dismissed per request pending suit.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kotta Annaprurnanma v. Makku Venkamma
precedents_cited.relevance: Not revival case.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kalliappa Goundan v. Kandaswami Goundan
precedents_cited.relevance: Not revival.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chunnamal v. Chennappa Goundan
precedents_cited.relevance: Previous pending per construction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Nagendra Nath Dey v. Suresh Chandra Dey
precedents_cited.relevance: Strict grammatical meaning in limitation.

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs limitation for execution applications; time exclusion for steps in aid, appeals, etc.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Foreclosure decree under O.34 r.3; execution by passing/sent court; written statement/set-off.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed by majority; fifth execution application held time-barred under Art.182 Limitation Act, 1908. High Court order upheld.
outcome.costs: Parties shall bear their own costs.

key_quotes.text: The rule of liberal construction gives a free hand to the Court to stretch and strain the statutory language to accord with our abstract notions of justice and fair play.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects liberal construction beyond statutory language for 'application' under Art.182(5).

key_quotes.text: Proper Court means the Court whose duty it is to execute the decree.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines proper court per Expl.II Art.182; High Court not proper.

key_quotes.text: These steps to remove the impeding [obstacle] ... were absolutely incumbent upon the appellant to take the next move in furtherance of the execution.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Dissent views resistance in collateral suit as step in aid.
